utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""LET'S GO CRAZY"")
Dearly beloved.
I love this skate so much.

And he did his short program to ""Let's Go Crazy"" by Prince.
Say no more.

Japan, he is as big as Steph Curry is here.
He is just an absolute star.
The way he brings the spins, you start to see Prince's music happening on the ice when you see Yuzuru Hanyu skate to it.

He's doing all of these different spins.
And they're incredibly difficult.
And he's earning a lot of points.
They're athletically difficult.
And even at one point he sort of takes his leg behind his head and plays it like he's playing a guitar.
(SOUNDBITE OF PRINCE SONG, ""LET'S GO CRAZY"")
So it sounds like a part of the idea, too, is just to attract young viewers to this sport.
Do you think that's working?
Yeah.
I think it's attracting young viewers because, I mean, when a figure skating program goes viral there's somebody watching that somewhere and saying, hey, maybe I can try figure skating.
And that is a huge part of the Olympics, is every sport gets a little bump.
It gets some people interested in it and trying it because they've saw it and they saw something in it.
And I don't know if all of the young kids out there would have necessarily seen something of themselves in the Rachmaninoff, but they sure as heck would see it in the Lil Jon version.
Maggie Hendricks, reporter at USA Today, thank you very much.
Thank you so much.
This was a blast.

And more now on port security.
Officials who monitor the ports say that irrespective of the Dubai deal, security remains a major concern.
But the real issue is money.
NPR's Mike Pesca reports.
Twenty-five thousand shipping containers, each the size of a small home, enter the nation's 361 ports each day.
The main security worry is that by the latest figures, only 5.6 percent of containers are pulled off ships or scanned with x-rays or gamma rays.
Michael O'Hanlon(ph), senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said the number is so low simply because we don't have the funding to inspect more.
Mr.
MICHAEL O'HANLON (Senior Fellow, Brookings Institution): My own instinct is that you got to be somewhere into the double figures range.
The reason why we're only at five percent is capacity.
It's not, there's no other reason why we're only inspecting one of 20 containers.
We just don't have enough people yet, don't have enough machines.
Of course if there was more money, most experts predict there would be tightened security.
How much more money?
Ms.
SUSAN MONTEVERDE(ph) (Vice President, American Association of Port Authorities): The funding level, last year Congress appropriated $175 million dollars.
We believe that the funding level should be $400 million dollars.
Susan Monteverde is the vice president of the American Association of Port Authorities.
She says our ports are safe but we're just doing the minimum.
The extra funding would be used for such programs as building emergency command centers or installing camera surveillance systems around ports that are relying on fences.
There has undoubtedly been improvement.
A little over a year ago, Henry Willis co-authored a report on port security for the Rand Corporation.
Since that time, some technology has proved effective.
Some hasn't.
Since we published our report, the department is moving forward with a container seal stand regulation.
And this is an example of good progress.
Our radio frequency identification is a technology that is getting mixed results.
All containers are scanned for radiation.
Which in the opinion of maritime security expert Rob Quartel is easily beaten by lead casing.
Most of us think radiation detectors are virtually useless too.

If you're a terrorist and you want to bring in fissile material, the basis for a nuclear weapon, the odds are you're going to put it in an oil tanker or a product tanker or a grain vessel or something else for which there's no external means of looking for the material.
In other words, as one part of the security grid tightens, another will spring a leak.
Sure.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

As for a dirty bomb, Quartel, who is CEO of FreightDesk Technologies and is a former federal maritime commissioner, said it's so easy for terrorists to assemble that kind of weapon from material available in America, there'd be little reason to ship it in.
Michael O'Hanlon paints a scenario where terrorists ship a hundred surface to air missiles to the U.S.
and reasonably hope that one or two get through the cracks in the system.
But there is near unanimity in the idea that port safety doesn't depend on keeping foreign companies from owning the rights to US terminals.
It depends on the US owning up to its own security obligations.
Mike Pesca, NPR News, New York.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
At the stroke of midnight on January 1st, many of us will embrace 2008 with new resolutions, new promises, new beginnings.
And at that same moment, a host of new laws take effect.
State and federal legislators spent much of this past year crafting laws, from the unusual to the controversial.
At 12:01 Pacific Time, you can get pulled over for texting while driving in California.
At 12:01 Central, revelers in Illinois will have to step outside to smoke their first cigarette of the new year.
Minnesotans will only be able to buy American flags made in the U.S.A.
And if you're stranded on the tarmac at JFK, pretzels and water will be headed your way by act of the New York state legislature.
More on that in just a moment.
Later in the hour, should the news media publish or broadcast the names of murderers whose motive is notoriety?
new laws.
What new measures take effect January 1st where you live?
E-mail us: talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.

We begin with New York state Assemblyman Michael Gianaris, who wrote a bill that takes effect on New Year's Day, which requires airlines to provide certain services to passengers when they're stranded on the tarmac.
He joins us from his office in Astoria in Queens, New York.
And nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
Thank you for having me, Neal.
And I gather, there was some personal experience behind your - behind this bill.
Well, anyone that's flown in and out of New York in the last couple of years has had a personal experience about being delayed on the tarmac.
So, yes, unfortunately, myself and many people I know have experienced this.
And there was one occasion in particular?
No.

Well, really what got us all going on it was back on Valentine's Day, there was an incident that everyone had heard of where passengers were stranded on planes for upwards of eight or nine hours and did not have - not only were they not offered food or water during that time, but the bathrooms were not cleaned out.
The air was not being ventilated.
And it became a lot more than an inconvenience.
It became a serious health concern.
And from that moment forward, we started working to make sure that New York at least had this protection since we are the home to the most delayed airports, unfortunately.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I think it's a - that's a mantra you'd proudly pass along to Chicago or Atlanta or some place else.
Or anywhere else, sure.
Yeah.
So what happens, now, starting January 1st, if you're on the tarmac in New York City, at JFK, say?
Well, starting January 1, if you're on the tarmac for three hours or more, the airlines are obligated to provide you with water and food.
They're obligated to clean the bathroom and make sure that the power is working so that the air is ventilated.
Should they not do that, passengers will have the right to register complaint with the new office of Airline Consumer Advocate in New York.
And if there are violations, the penalties can run up to $1,000 per passenger, so it's a pretty stiff fine at the airlines could incur if they don't provide these basic services.
I'm sure the airlines have come back at you and said, hey, wait a minute.
We've got four zillion federal regulations to deal with here.
We don't need more from the state of New York.
Well, as a matter of fact, they sued us in the federal court to strike down the law.

If you believe it - believe it or not, the airlines went to court, spent their money on lawyers to argue that passengers are not entitled to a drink or water after being stuck for three hours on the tarmac.
